titleStmt.title: A machine-readable profile of Damscus Arabic
titleStmt.author: Naima Sekiati

sourceDesc.p: This is an original digital text

div.p: Urban (prehilalien), sedentary dialect with bedouin influence

Basically, the dialect of Salé is almost identical to that of Rabat. The varieties of both cities were strongly influenced by the impact of Bedouin infiltration mainly in the second half of the past century and the large numbers of Berbers who settled in the outskirts in the same period.

By contrast to the old dialect of Rabat (L. Brunot 1920ff.), there exist no in-depth studies of the dialect of the medina of Salé. It can be assumed that the old dialect of Salé (as is stated for Rabat) had similar basic features as Tanger and Tetouan speech. The development from an „urban“ to a „mixed rural-urban“ dialect is described by Messaoudi (2002). Recent grammatical and lexical studies on Rabat/Salé have been undertaken by Heath (2002) and Behnstedt (2011/12).
